سورہ یونس کی آیت طاقت کے ساتھ عارضی طور پر دنیاوی لالچ کو ایمان کو مسترد کرنے کے دائمی نتائج سے متصادم ہے۔ اللہ نے اس زندگی میں کافروں کے مختصر لطف اندوزی (*ماتاون*) کو بیان کیا ہے - ایک ایسی اصطلاح جس کا مطلب یہ ہے کہ وہ مادی راحتوں کا مطلب ہے۔ ان کی حتمی قسمت "شدید سزا" (*العدحاب الشادد*) ہے جس کے نتیجے میں ان کے جان بوجھ کر انکار (*کوفر*) الہی سچائی ہے۔ تاریخی طور پر ، یہ آیت مکہ میں اس وقت سامنے آئی جب ابتدائی مسلمانوں کو قریش کے رہنماؤں کی طرف سے شدید ظلم و ستم کا سامنا کرنا پڑا جنہوں نے دولت اور اقتدار سے چمٹے رہتے ہوئے خدائی انتباہ کا مذاق اڑایا۔ آیت نے مومنوں کو یقین دلایا کہ دنیاوی تکبر برقرار نہیں رہے گا اور انصاف کے بعد کی زندگی میں انصاف ہوگا۔

کلیدی شرائط اس پیغام کو واضح کرتی ہیں: * ماتاون * (عارضی فائدہ) زندگی کی عدم استحکام کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے ، جبکہ * مارجیوہم * (ان کی واپسی) احتساب پر زور دیتی ہے۔ یہ ایک بنیادی اسلامی اصول ہے۔ "شدید سزا" توبہ کے بغیر ایمان کو مسترد کرنے کی کشش کو اجاگر کرتی ہے۔ الامہ تبتابائی جیسے مبصرین نے وضاحت کی ہے کہ * کوفر * یہاں محض لاعلمی نہیں ہے بلکہ ثبوت کے باوجود سچائی کو قبول کرنے سے شعوری طور پر انکار ہے ، جیسا کہ فرعون جیسے تکبر میں دیکھا گیا ہے۔

جدید مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت فوری سبق پیش کرتی ہے۔ مادیت اور فوری تسکین کے جنون میں مبتلا عمر میں ، یہ ہمیں تیز تر خواہشات پر ابدی اہداف کو ترجیح دینے کی یاد دلاتا ہے۔ یہ معاشرتی حیثیت ، غیر اخلاقی منافع یا ہیڈونزم کے لئے سمجھوتہ کرنے والے ایمان کے خلاف متنبہ کرتا ہے۔ عملی طور پر ، اس میں خود کی عکاسی کا مطالبہ کیا گیا ہے: کیا ہم روحانی نشوونما کو نظرانداز کرتے ہوئے * ماتاون * کا پیچھا کر رہے ہیں؟ کیا ہم ذاتی یا معاشرتی معاملات میں تکبر کے ساتھ خدائی رہنمائی کو مسترد کر رہے ہیں؟ یہ آیت بھی امید کو متاثر کرتی ہے - ابتدائی مسلمانوں کی طرح سچائی کو برقرار رکھنے کے لئے بھی مقدمے کا سامنا کرنا پڑتا ہے ، جیسے ہی برداشت کرتے ہیں ، عارضی ہیں ، جبکہ الہی انصاف ابدی ہے۔ اکیرہ پر مبنی ارادوں کے ساتھ دنیاوی ذمہ داریوں کو متوازن کرکے ، مسلمان جان بوجھ کر زندگی گزار سکتے ہیں ، اور اس بات کی یقین کے ساتھ کاموں کو سیدھ کر سکتے ہیں کہ "ہمارے نزدیک ان کی واپسی ہے۔
70.layer2_urdu:
سورہ یونس (10:70) میں ، اللہ کافروں کے لئے دنیاوی لذت کی حقیقت پسندی کی وضاحت کرتا ہے ، اس کے بعد اس میں ان کی ناگزیر واپسی اور اس کے نتیجے میں عذاب پیدا ہوتا ہے۔ کلاسیکی شیعہ استثنیٰ ، جیسے*المزان*میں علامہ تبتابائی اور*ماجما البیان*میں شیخ تبریسی ، ان کی تشریحات کو خدائی انصاف کے مذہبی ستونوں (*‘ADL*) میں لنگر انداز کرتے ہیں اور عارضی دنیاوی وجود (*ڈنیا*) اور ابدی حقیقت (*اوکیرہ*) کے مابین اونٹولوجیکل امتیاز۔ 

تبریسی ،*مجسما البیان*میں ، اس بات کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے کہ کافروں کو دی جانے والی "لطف" (*ماتا oun ن*) اللہ کی رواداری (*استدریج*) کا مظہر ہے ، جس سے انہیں عارضی مہلت کی اجازت دی جاسکتی ہے یا ان کی خود سے ناپسندیدہ کھنڈرات کو گہرا کیا جاسکتا ہے۔ یہ قرآنی اس اصول کے مطابق ہے کہ دنیاوی خوشحالی نہ تو الہی احسان کی علامت ہے اور نہ ہی اپنے آپ میں ایک اختتام بلکہ ایک آزمائش (*ابٹیلا ’*) ہے۔ تبتابائی نے اس پر توسیع کی ، یہ نوٹ کرتے ہوئے کہ اس طرح کے بیڑے ہوئے لذتیں *ڈنیا *کی فطری طور پر کمی کی نوعیت سے لازم و ملزوم ہیں۔ "ہمارے پاس واپسی" (*مارجی iuhumum*) کو محض جسمانی موت کے طور پر نہیں بلکہ اس کے تخلیق کار کے لئے روح کی طرف سے احتساب کے لئے اس کے تخلیق کار کی طرف سے تعبیر کیا جاتا ہے ، یہ ایک عمل شیعہ اسکیٹولوجی کے لئے لازمی ہے ، جو AHL البیٹ کی شفاعت کے تحت*برزخ*(انٹرمیڈیٹ دائرے) کے ذریعے روح کے سفر پر زور دیتا ہے۔

آیت کا "شدید سزا" کے حوالے سے (*العدحب الشادد*) کا حوالہ*کوفر*(کفر) کی شیعہ تفہیم میں ہے کیونکہ توہید کو مسترد کرنے اور الہی مقرر کردہ امامیٹ کی بدنامی دونوں کو شامل کیا گیا ہے۔ کلاسیکی اسکالرز ، امام جعفر السادق کی روایات پر روشنی ڈالتے ہوئے ، اس بات پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ * کوفر * یہاں امام علی کے ولیہ کے انکار بھی شامل ہے ، اس طرح نظریاتی انحراف کو وجودی نتائج سے جوڑتا ہے۔ یہ شیعہ محور کے ساتھ منسلک ہے کہ اماموں کی اطاعت اللہ کی اطاعت سے لازم و ملزوم ہے ، کیونکہ وہ خدائی رہنمائی (*ہجاہ*) کے متولی ہیں۔

فقہی طور پر ، آیت اس کے بعد کے ابدی فریم ورک کے ساتھ دنیاوی اقدامات کی صف بندی کی ضرورت کو تقویت بخشتی ہے۔ عارضی*ماتاون*مادیت کے خلاف احتیاط کا کام کرتا ہے ، اور اخلاقی اور رسمی قوانین (*احکام*) پر عمل پیرا ہونے پر زور دیتا ہے جو اے ایچ ایل ال بائٹ کے ذریعے منتقل ہوتا ہے۔ اس طرح ، آیت الہیات ، اسکیٹولوجی ، اور قانون کی ترکیب کرتی ہے ، اور مومنوں کو یاد دلاتی ہے کہ حقیقی کامیابی *ڈنیا *کی فریب کاری کو تسلیم کرنے اور خود کو اماموں کی برائٹ رہنمائی میں لنگر انداز کرنے میں مضمر ہے۔
70.layer3_urdu:
سورہ یونس (10:70) میں ، قرآن مجید دنیاوی طور پر ابدی احتساب کے ساتھ عارضی طور پر مبتلا ہوجاتا ہے۔ وہ "اس دنیا میں لطف اندوز" کو ہائپر مادیت پسندی کے خلاف احتیاط کے طور پر تیار کرتا ہے ، جہاں معاشرے معاشی نمو ، صارفیت ، یا اخلاقی بنیادوں سے منقطع ہونے والے تکنیکی ترقی کو ترجیح دیتے ہیں۔ یہ نفسیاتی مطالعات سے گونجتا ہے ، جیسے ڈینیئل گلبرٹ یا میہلی سیسکزنٹمیہلی کے ذریعہ ، یہ انکشاف کرتا ہے کہ مادی زیادتی اکثر وجودی خالی پن کے ساتھ منسلک ہوتی ہے ، اور قرآنی انتباہ کے ساتھ صف بندی کرتے ہیں کہ دنیاوی فوائد روحانی مقصد کے بغیر چل رہے ہیں۔  

ڈاکٹر محمد علی شومالی جیسے ہم عصر مفکرین آیت کو آج کے بحرانوں سے جوڑتے ہیں: ماحولیاتی انحطاط جو نکالنے والے سرمایہ داری ، سیسٹیمیٹک عدم مساوات ، یا ڈیجیٹل فرار کو ماسک کرتے ہوئے فرقہ وارانہ بیگانگی کو نقاب پوش کرتے ہیں۔ "شدید سزا" محض اسکیوٹولوجیکل نہیں ہے بلکہ معاشرتی خاتمے میں ظاہر ہوتی ہے۔ آیت کی کفر (کفر) کو عبور کرنے کی کال اخلاقی بے حسی کو مسترد کرنے تک پھیلی ہوئی ہے ، چاہے وہ آب و ہوا کی سائنس سے انکار کرے ، پسماندہ طبقات کا استحصال کرے ، یا لالچ کو معمول بنائے۔  

انٹرفیتھ متوازی اس مکالمے کو گہرا کرتے ہیں۔ امپیریننس (انیکا) اور دولت کے عیسائی نقادوں سے متعلق بدھ مت کی تعلیمات (متی 6: 19-21) اخلاقی چوکسی کے ساتھ دنیاوی مشغولیت کو متوازن کرنے پر قرآنی اصرار کی بازگشت کرتے ہیں۔ کثیر الثقافتی معاشرے مشترکہ انسانی وقار کو مسترد کرنے کے طور پر "کفر" کی ترجمانی کرسکتے ہیں۔  

امام علی کی مشیر - "یہ دنیا ایک عبارت ہے ، مستقل ٹھکانہ نہیں ہے" - شیعہ اسکالرز کو پائیدار ترقی اور معاشرتی انصاف کی وکالت کرنے پر مجبور کرتا ہے۔ "ہمارے پاس واپسی" کائناتی احتساب کا ایک استعارہ بن جاتا ہے: ہر عمل ماحولیاتی اور معاشرتی نظاموں کے ذریعے بہتا ہے ، اور اسٹیورشپ (خلیفہ) کا مطالبہ کرتا ہے۔ اے آئی اور آب و ہوا کی غیر یقینی صورتحال کے دور میں ، یہ آیت معاشروں سے گزارش کرتی ہے کہ وہ صرف جی ڈی پی کے ذریعہ نہیں بلکہ اخلاقی لچک کے ذریعہ پیشرفت کی پیمائش کرے۔  

آخر کار ، یونس 10:70 ایک بازیافت کی دعوت دیتا ہے: انصاف سے طلاق شدہ خوشحالی غربت ہے۔ جیسا کہ عصری مذہبی ماہر رضا شاہ-کاظمی نوٹ کرتے ہیں ، الہی اتحاد (توہید) کو تسلیم کرنے کا مطلب ہے کہ ساری زندگی کا باہمی ربط دیکھنا-ایک سچائی جدید چیلنجوں کا مطالبہ ہے جس کا ہم مجسم ہیں۔
70.layer4_urdu:
سورہ یونس کی آیت ایک بالکل یاد دہانی کا کام کرتی ہے کہ دنیاوی لذتیں بحری جہاز ہیں اور یہ کہ حتمی حساب کتاب خدائی انصاف میں ہے۔ اہل بیت (ان پر امن) نے یہ سکھایا کہ یہ عارضی دنیا ایمان کی آزمائش ہے اور ابدی سچائیوں سے ہماری وابستگی کا عکاس ہے۔ امام علی (ع) نے کہا ، * "یہ دنیا کسی منافع کے لئے ایک بازار ہے - کچھ منافع اور کچھ ہار جاتے ہیں۔" * جو لوگ جو اس آیت میں "شدید سزا" کا سامنا کرنے والے دیرپا روحانی حقائق پر عارضی لطف اندوز ہونے کو ترجیح دیتے ہیں ، جو اللہ کی رہنمائی اور اس کے منتخب کردہ رہنماؤں کے الہی اتھارٹی کو مسترد کرنے سے پیدا ہوتا ہے۔  

اس آیت سے منسلک ایک وسطی شیعہ مذہبی تصور *ولیہ *ہے ، جو نبی of کی روحانی سرپرستی اور اس کی پاکیزہ اولاد ہے۔ ایمان کے اس بنیادی ستون کو مسترد کرنا * کوفر * (کفر) سے الگ نہیں ہے ، جیسا کہ امام محمد البقیر (ع) نے وضاحت کی: "اسلام پانچ [ستونوں] پر بنایا گیا ہے: دعا ، خیرات ، روزہ ، روزہ ، حج اور ولی att ں کو کسی بھی چیز کو نہیں بلایا گیا ہے جس کو پہچاننے کے بعد بھی ان کو نہیں سمجھا گیا ہے۔ خطرہ کھوکھلا ہونے کا خطرہ ہے ، کیونکہ حقیقی پیش کرنے کے لئے اماموں کے سپرد الہی روشنی کی وفاداری کی ضرورت ہے۔  

لیڈی فاطمہ (ع) نے اپنے مشہور خطبہ میں دنیاوی فوائد کے فریب دہ رغبت کے خلاف متنبہ کیا: * "آپ کو خوشیوں میں ڈوبی ہوئی رہتی ہے ، بیکار خواہشات کا تعاقب کرتے ہوئے ... جبکہ اللہ کی کتاب اور اس کی ذمہ داریوں کو ضائع کردیا گیا ہے۔"  

عملی روحانی رہنمائی اس آیت سے ابھری ہے: مومنین کو اہل بیت کی تعلیمات میں خود کو لنگر انداز کرکے دنیاوی فریبوں سے لاتعلقی کاشت کرنا چاہئے۔ امام جعفر السادق (ع) نے مشورہ دیا ، * "موت کی یاد کے ل your اپنے دل کو ایک پناہ گاہ بنائیں ، اور آپ کے اعمال کو واپسی کے دن کی تیاری۔" * دنیاوی فوائد کی عارضی نوعیت کی باقاعدگی سے عکاسی ، جس کے ساتھ ساتھ اماموں کے اخلاقی اور روحانی پروگراموں کے خلاف مخلصانہ طور پر عمل پیرا بھی ہے۔  

بالآخر ، یہ آیت ہمیں الہی انصاف کے دائمی پیمانے کے ساتھ اپنی ترجیحات کی صف بندی کرنے کا مطالبہ کرتی ہے ، اور یہ تسلیم کرتے ہوئے کہ حقیقی کامیابی لمحہ بہ لمحہ خوشیوں میں نہیں بلکہ اپنے منتخب رہنماؤں کے لئے محبت کے ذریعہ اللہ کی خوشی حاصل کرنے اور ان کی لازوال حکمت کی تعمیل کرنے میں ہے۔
70.layer5:
Both Shia and Sunni exegetical traditions converge on the core theological themes of this verse: the transient nature of worldly life, divine justice in the hereafter, and the inevitability of accountability for disbelief (*kufr*). Al-Tabari (Sunni) and al-Tabrisi (Shia) similarly emphasize that worldly enjoyment (*mataʿ*) is fleeting and ultimately inconsequential compared to eternal consequences, framing the verse as a warning against prioritizing material pursuits over spiritual truth. Ibn Kathir (Sunni) and al-Tabtabai (Shia) both contextualize the verse within the broader Quranic discourse on resurrection, underscoring Allah’s omnipotence in administering recompense.  

A key divergence lies in the interpretation of *kufr* (disbelief) and its implications. Sunni commentators like al-Qurtubi and al-Razi often define *kufr* broadly as rejection of prophetic truth, focusing on the moral responsibility of individuals to heed divine guidance. In contrast, Shia sources such as al-Qummi and al-Tusi, while agreeing on this baseline, occasionally integrate the concept of *kufr* as including rejection of *wilayah* (divinely ordained leadership of the Ahl al-Bayt). This reflects the Shia theological principle that true belief necessitates acceptance of both prophethood and Imamah.  

Historically, these differences stem from distinct epistemological frameworks. Sunni exegesis often prioritizes the Prophet’s teachings as transmitted through the broader community (*sahaba*), while Shia tafsir heavily relies on narrations from the Imams, viewed as inheritors of prophetic knowledge. For instance, al-Tabtabai’s *Al-Mizan* interprets the “severe punishment” as a consequence of rejecting both divine messages and their rightful interpreters, whereas al-Razi’s *Mafatih al-Ghayb* emphasizes individual moral agency without explicit reference to leadership.  

These interpretations subtly shape religious practice: Sunni discourse often reinforces adherence to Quranic ethics and communal orthodoxy, while Shia thought intertwines spiritual accountability with loyalty to the Imams. Despite these nuances, both traditions uphold the verse’s central message—a reminder of life’s temporality and the gravity of ultimate judgment—reflecting shared ethical and eschatological concerns across Islamic schools of thought.

71.layer1:
In Surah Yunus, verse 71, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to recount the story of Prophet Nuh (Noah) as a lesson for his contemporaries. The verse captures Nuh's bold address to his people after enduring centuries of rejection: "O my people, if my presence among you and my reminders of Allah’s signs have become unbearable, know that I place my trust entirely in Allah." Here, Nuh demonstrates *tawakkul* (reliance on God) while challenging his opponents to unite their efforts against him and "resolve their plan" (*ajmoo amrakum*) alongside their false gods, urging them to act decisively without hesitation (*la takun amrukum ghummah* – "let not your plan be obscure"). This direct challenge reflects both Nuh’s unwavering conviction and his readiness to face persecution for truth.  

Historically, this Meccan verse reassured the early Muslim community facing persecution, illustrating that prophets before them endured similar trials. The term *nabaa* (news/narrative) emphasizes storytelling as a tool for moral instruction. The phrase *tadhkeeri bi-ayati Allah* ("my reminding of Allah’s signs") highlights the prophetic duty to persistently convey divine guidance, even when met with hostility.  

For modern Muslims, this verse teaches resilience in upholding faith amidst societal pressures. Nuh’s example encourages believers to trust in Allah (*tawakkul*) rather than compromising principles for social acceptance. The call to "resolve your plan" challenges contemporary Muslims to confront collective moral crises with clarity and unity, whether combating injustice or promoting ethical values. Just as Nuh’s patience spanned centuries, this verse reminds us that defending truth requires perseverance, strategic action, and unshakable reliance on Divine support—a timeless blueprint for navigating trials with dignity and purpose.
71.layer2:
In Surah Yunus verse 71, the Quran recounts Prophet Noah’s (AS) decisive confrontation with his people, encapsulating themes of prophetic resolve, divine reliance (*tawakkul*), and the futility of shirk. Classical Shia commentators emphasize the theological and ethical dimensions of this exchange, drawing lessons for the enduring struggle between divine truth and polytheistic arrogance. 

Al-Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* interprets Noah’s declaration, *“If my residence and my reminding of Allah’s signs has become burdensome upon you,”* as a reflection of the recurring Quranic motif of prophets facing rejection for embodying divine truth. The phrase *“my reminding”* (*tadhkiri*) underscores the prophetic duty to awaken spiritual consciousness, a theme central to Shia thought, which views the Imams as inheritors of this role. Noah’s challenge to his people to *“resolve upon your plan and [call upon] your associates”* is understood as an exposé of the emptiness of polytheism. The “associates” (*shuraka’*), as Al-Tabrisi notes, refer to idols or false deities, whose incapacity to aid their devotees foreshadows the inevitable collapse of disbelief—a principle reinforcing *tawhid* (divine oneness).

Al-Tabtabai in *Al-Mizan* delves deeper into the ontological implications of Noah’s reliance on Allah (*fa-‘ala Allahi tawakkaltu*), framing it as the epitome of *tawakkul*—total surrender to divine will, a virtue exemplified by the Ahl al-Bayt (AS). The command *“then carry it out upon me and do not give me respite”* is interpreted as a challenge to the disbelievers’ temporal power, asserting that Allah’s decree transcends human plots. This aligns with the Shia theological tenet that divine support (*nusrah*) ultimately prevails, even amid apparent worldly defeat.

The verse also resonates with Shia jurisprudence’s emphasis on steadfastness (*thabat*) in adversity. Noah’s unwavering stance mirrors the moral and spiritual resolve expected of believers, particularly in confronting oppression—a theme echoed in the narratives of Imam Husayn (AS) at Karbala. Furthermore, the call to clarity in action (*“let not your plan be obscure to you”*) underscores Islam’s rejection of moral and intellectual ambiguity, urging conscious accountability—a principle foundational to Shia ethical theology.

In sum, this verse encapsulates the Shia worldview: truth-tellers face resistance, yet their reliance on Allah and commitment to divine mission remain unshaken, prefiguring the eternal triumph of *haqq* (truth) over *batil* (falsehood)
71.layer3:
In Surah Yunus, verse 71, the story of Prophet Noah becomes a resonant call for moral courage and intellectual integrity in modern times. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, emphasize Noah’s unwavering commitment to truth despite societal rejection, framing his challenge to his people—*resolve your plan and act*—as a timeless lesson in confronting oppressive systems. This verse underscores the prophet’s radical trust in divine justice (*tawakkul*) while rejecting complacency, a duality that speaks to today’s activists and truth-seekers navigating authoritarianism, climate denial, or systemic injustice.  

Modern thinkers like philosopher Sayyid Kamal al-Haydari connect Noah’s defiance to the necessity of intellectual independence in an age of misinformation. The verse’s critique of *shuraka* (false associates) mirrors contemporary critiques of ideological idolatry—whether consumerism, nationalism, or algorithmic echo chambers—that distract societies from ethical clarity. Neuroscience research on "groupthink" aligns with the Quranic warning against letting *your plan be obscure*: collective decisions rooted in bias or fear often lack the discernment demanded by crises like ecological collapse or polarization.  

Noah’s story also bridges interfaith dialogues, resonating with Judeo-Christian narratives of resilience and Hindu teachings on *dharma* (duty). Multiculturally, it invites reflection on how marginalized voices—akin to Noah’s isolated warnings—are dismissed as inconvenient truths. The demand to *not give me respite* parallels urgent calls for climate action, where delaying justice deepens harm.  

In essence, this verse challenges modern believers to embrace prophetic audacity: trusting divine wisdom while actively dismantling societal delusions. It’s a manifesto for ethical perseverance—whether confronting corporate greed, advocating for refugees, or rebuilding trust in fractured communities. As scholar Fatema Al-Mesbah notes, Noah’s legacy isn’t merely survival; it’s the courage to speak truth *before* the flood.
71.layer4:
In this profound verse recounting Prophet Noah’s unwavering stand against his people’s rejection, the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) illuminate timeless lessons on divine reliance, spiritual courage, and the essence of *wilayah* (divine guardianship). When Noah declares, *“I have relied upon Allah,”* Imam Ali (as) teaches in *Nahj al-Balagha*: “Reliance on Allah is the price of every precious thing and the ladder to every exalted goal.” Here, Noah embodies the Shia ethos of *tawakkul*—total trust in Allah’s plan, even when facing existential threats. This mirrors Imam Hussein’s (as) stance at Karbala, where he declared: “I see nothing but beauty in sacrifice for the sake of Allah.” Both Noah and the Imams demonstrate that true reliance on Allah transforms worldly weakness into spiritual strength.  

The verse’s challenge—“resolve upon your plan”—reveals a recurring divine test: the clash between truth and falsehood. The Ahlul Bayt taught that every believer faces such trials, as Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) said: “The believer is like a mountain—winds cannot shake it.” To withstand such tests, Lady Fatimah (as) emphasized the power of *dhikr* (remembrance of Allah), stating: “Allah made faith your purification from polytheism… and remembrance a shield against whispers.” Constant remembrance, coupled with allegiance to divine guides, fortifies the soul against doubt.  

Noah’s call to “not give me respite” carries profound wisdom. The Imams taught that delaying spiritual accountability leads to self-deception. Imam Ali (as) warned: “The tomorrow you wait for is closer than the yesterday that passed.” Practically, this urges believers to embrace *taqwa* (God-consciousness) proactively, aligning every action with the *sirat al-mustaqeem* (straight path) under the guidance of the Ahlul Bayt.  

The *wilayah* of the Imams, as the living continuation of prophetic mission, teaches that divine support (*nusrah*) accompanies those who uphold truth with sincerity. As Noah stood firm despite mockery, the believer today must anchor themselves in the teachings of the Imams, whose luminous legacy provides a roadmap through darkness. Imam al-Baqir (as) said: “Our love is faith, and our hatred is disbelief”—a reminder that true reliance on Allah necessitates unwavering allegiance to His chosen guides.  

Let this verse inspire us to embody Noah’s resoluteness, the Imams’ courage, and Fatimah’s devotion, transforming trials into steps toward divine proximity through trust, remembrance, and unshakable commitment to the path of the Ahlul Bayt.

71.layer5:
In interpreting Yunus 10:71, Shia and Sunni scholars exhibit both convergence and divergence in their exegetical approaches. Classical commentators across traditions, including Tabari and Tabatabai, agree on the verse’s core narrative: Noah’s courageous challenge to his people to abandon idolatry and confront him openly if they reject his message. Both traditions emphasize Noah’s unwavering *tawakkul* (reliance on God) as a model for believers, with Qurtubi and Tusi noting the linguistic force of “fa-ajmiʿū amrakum” (resolve your plan) as a rhetorical device underscoring the futility of opposing divine truth.  

Key differences emerge in theological emphasis. Shia sources like Al-Mizan and Majma al-Bayan highlight Noah’s role as a *divinely protected guide*, with Tabatabai framing his challenge as a paradigm for the Ahl al-Bayt’s spiritual resistance to oppression. Sunni commentators such as Ibn Kathir and Razi focus more on the communal moral lesson, interpreting “shurakāʾakum” (your associates) as a rebuke of polytheism’s irrationality, aligning with broader Sunni emphasis on *tawhid*’s logical supremacy.  

The verse’s directive to “not give me respite” is interpreted by Qummi as an allusion to eschatological urgency, reflecting Shia eschatological themes, while Tabari and Qurtubi read it pragmatically, stressing the inevitability of divine punishment. These nuances reflect distinct theological frameworks: Shia *tafsir* often integrates Imamology and theodicy, whereas Sunni exegesis prioritizes communal ethics and historical precedent.  

Historically, these divergences stem from differing hermeneutical priorities shaped by early theological debates. Shia scholars, influenced by the Imamah doctrine, often read prophetic narratives through the lens of divinely guided leadership, while Sunni exegetes, grounded in preserving communal consensus, emphasize legal and moral universals. Despite these variations, both traditions unite in upholding Noah’s steadfastness as a timeless exemplar of faith confronting disbelief.

71.summary: Tafsir al-Mizan offers profound insights, with Tabatabai noting that delves deeper into the ontological implications of Noah’s reliance on Allah (*fa-‘ala Allahi tawakkaltu*), framing it as the epitome of *tawakkul*—total surrender to divine will, a virtue exemplified by the Ahl al-Bayt (AS). In Surah Yunus, verse 71, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to recount the story of Prophet Nuh (Noah) as a lesson for his contemporaries. The verse captures Nuh's bold address to his people after enduring centuries of rejection: "O my people, if my presence among you and my reminders of Allah’s signs have become unbearable, know that I place my trust entirely in Allah. " Here, Nuh demonstrates *tawakkul* (reliance on God) while challenging his opponents to unite their efforts against him and "resolve their plan" (*ajmoo amrakum*) alongside their false gods, urging them to act decisively without hesitation (*la takun amrukum ghummah* – "let not your plan be obscure"). Imam Ali (as) teaches in *Nahj al-Balagha*: “Reliance on Allah is the price of every precious thing and the ladder to every exalted goal. This verse teaches resilience in upholding faith amidst societal pressures.

72.layer1:
In Surah Yunus, verse 72, Prophet Nuh (Noah) addresses his disbelieving community with a profound declaration of faith and integrity. The verse captures his response to their rejection: *"If you turn away [from my advice], then no payment have I asked of you. My reward is only from Allah, and I have been commanded to be of the Muslims."* Here, Nuh underscores that his mission is not motivated by worldly gain but by divine purpose. The term *tawallaytum* ("you turn away") reflects the people’s deliberate rejection of truth, while *ajr* ("reward") emphasizes that prophets seek compensation solely from Allah, not people. The phrase *min al-muslimeen* ("of the Muslims") highlights total submission to Allah’s commands, defining Islam’s essence as surrender to divine will.  

Historically, this verse echoes Nuh’s centuries-long struggle to guide his people, who mocked his calls to monotheism. Despite their persistent denial, he remained steadfast, embodying the prophets’ timeless role: conveying truth without compromise, regardless of reception. His declaration *"I have been commanded to be of the Muslims"* reaffirms that prophethood itself is rooted in obedience to Allah, not personal ambition.  

For contemporary Muslims, this verse teaches sincerity in faith and detachment from worldly validation. It calls believers to prioritize Allah’s pleasure over human approval, whether in spreading goodness, upholding justice, or practicing faith. Just as Nuh trusted Allah’s reward system, Muslims today are reminded to perform acts of worship and moral conduct without seeking praise or material gain. The verse also inspires resilience: when faced with rejection or indifference, one’s duty is to remain committed to truth, leaving outcomes to Allah. By internalizing Nuh’s example, Muslims strengthen their identity as *muslimeen*—those who submit wholly to divine guidance in an age of shifting values.
72.layer2:
In Surah Yunus (10:72), Prophet Nuh’s declaration encapsulates profound theological and ethical principles central to Shia exegesis. Classical commentators such as Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* emphasize this verse’s dual focus on the prophetic rejection of worldly compensation and the ontological imperative of submission (*islam*) to divine command. The verse’s assertion, "My reward is only from Allah," is interpreted as a rejection not merely of material gain but of any transactional relationship between prophetic guidance and human reciprocity. As Tabatabai elucidates, this underscores the *wilayah* (divinely ordained authority) of prophets, whose missions derive solely from Allah’s wisdom, transcending human valuation. The prophets’ detachment from worldly recompense affirms their role as pure channels of divine truth, untainted by personal interest—a theme echoed in the conduct of the Ahl al-Bayt, who similarly eschewed worldly power despite their right to leadership.

The phrase "I have been commanded to be of the Muslims" is particularly significant in Shia theology. Tabrisi notes that this transcends literal "submission," instead denoting complete ontological alignment with divine will—a state epitomized by the *ma‘sumin* (infallibles). For Shia scholars, this aligns with the concept of *taslim* (total surrender), which encompasses not only adherence to ritual law but unwavering fidelity to the Imamah as a pillar of faith. The verse thus implicitly affirms the necessity of recognizing and following divinely appointed guides, as Nuh’s submission prefigures the loyalty owed to the Imams of the Ahl al-Bayt. 

Moreover, the verse’s theological framework intersects with Shia jurisprudence. The rejection of prophetic compensation reinforces the principle that religious authority cannot be commodified—a stance mirrored in the rejection of illegitimate caliphate systems by the Imams. The coupling of *ajr* (reward) with *amr* (command) in the verse underscores the integration of ethical purity and doctrinal obedience, foundational to Shia spirituality. In this light, the verse becomes a manifesto for the inseparable union of divine justice (*‘adl*) and guided leadership (*imamah*), principles that define Shia Islam’s distinct theological identity.
72.layer3:
In Surah Yunus (10:72), Prophet Nuh’s declaration—“If you turn away, I’ve asked no reward from you; my reward is with Allah, and I am commanded to be among those who submit”—resonates powerfully in our age of transactional relationships and moral ambiguity. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Sayyed Mohammad Ali Abtahi, emphasize how this verse critiques systems that instrumentalize faith for power or profit. In a world where religious authority is often entangled with political agendas or financial exploitation, Nuh’s refusal to seek earthly compensation becomes a radical model of integrity. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi notes that this verse underscores Islam’s call to prioritize spiritual accountability over material validation, urging leaders and communities to align their actions with divine purpose rather than世俗 gains.

Psychologically, the verse speaks to intrinsic motivation—a concept validated by modern studies showing that purpose-driven actions foster resilience and ethical consistency. Prophet Nuh’s detachment from reward mirrors findings in behavioral science: when individuals act out of conviction rather than external incentives, their efforts sustain transformative impact. This aligns with movements addressing climate justice or poverty, where activists like Malala Yousafzai or grassroots organizers exemplify selfless dedication akin to Nuh’s stance.

Socially, the verse challenges the commodification of spirituality in an age of “prosperity gospel” or extremist fundraising. It calls for religious institutions to rebuild trust through transparency, echoing Shia theologian Mohsen Kadivar’s advocacy for ethical governance rooted in *Tawhid* (divine unity). Globally, the principle of selfless service bridges interfaith efforts—Buddhist compassion (*karuna*), Christian charity, and Islamic *zakat* all share this ethos. In multicultural societies, Nuh’s message invites unity against greed and oppression, framing submission to Allah as a universal commitment to justice. By grounding action in divine accountability, the verse becomes a timeless blueprint for navigating today’s crises with principled humility.
72.layer4:
In this profound verse from Surah Yunus, the eternal voice of Allah’s chosen guides echoes through time, reminding humanity of the sacred principles upheld by the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them). When Prophet Noah declares, *"My reward is only from Allah,"* he embodies the essence of *ikhlas* (sincerity) taught by the Imams. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in Nahj al-Balagha: *"The reward of an action lies in the sincerity of its intention."* This purity of purpose, free from worldly desire or human validation, is the cornerstone of faith. The Ahlul Bayt exemplified this truth: Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) famously rejected worldly compensation for her rights, choosing instead the "pleasure of Allah and pursuit of the Hereafter," as narrated in *Bihar al-Anwar*. Their lives teach us that true worship flows from recognizing Allah as the only source of worth and recompense.

The phrase *"I have been commanded to be of the Muslims"* unveils the reality of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship). To be a *Muslim* in the fullest sense is to submit to Allah’s appointed guides. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) clarifies: *"Islam is witnessed by outward submission, while true faith [Iman] is an inward reality anchored in recognizing the Imam’s authority"* (Al-Kafi). Thus, submission transcends ritual—it is allegiance to the divine chain of Imamat, the luminous path preserved by the Ahlul Bayt. Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family) emphasized this in Ghadir Khumm, declaring Imam Ali’s leadership as inseparable from the faith itself.

Practically, this verse calls believers to detach from material motives and anchor their spiritual journey in divine connection. Imam Zayn al-Abidin (peace be upon him) guides us in *Sahifa al-Sajjadiyya*: *"Make my deeds free from seeking anyone but You, and purify them from the dust of vanity."* Daily reflection on intentions, coupled with studying the Ahlul Bayt’s selfless struggles, polishes the heart. Let every prayer, charity, and moral act be a mirror reflecting our love for Allah’s pleasure alone. By internalizing the Imamah’s light, we transform ordinary acts into vessels of eternal grace, embodying the verse’s timeless call to sincere, wilayah-centered surrender.

In interpreting Surah Yunus 10:72, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core themes of prophetic sincerity and divine reliance. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) emphasize Prophet Noah’s detachment from worldly compensation, framing his declaration as a model of selfless devotion to God’s command. Ibn Kathir and Al-Tusi similarly highlight the verse’s universal message: prophets seek no earthly reward, deriving authority solely from Allah. The phrase “I have been commanded to be of the Muslims” is broadly understood across traditions as affirming total submission (islam) to divine will, transcending temporal or sectarian boundaries.

Divergences emerge in contextualizing “the Muslims.” Sunni commentators like Al-Qurtubi and Al-Razi interpret this as a general call to monotheistic submission, aligning with Quranic universalism. In contrast, Shia scholars such as Al-Tabatabai and Al-Qummi contextualize the term within the framework of divine guidance (imamah), viewing Noah’s submission as inseparable from allegiance to God’s chosen successors—a thematic precursor to Shia concepts of prophetic and Imamic authority. This reflects the Shia theological emphasis on the necessity of divinely appointed leadership for maintaining true islam.

Historically, these differences stem from distinct developments in post-prophetic authority structures. Sunni exegesis evolved within caliphate-centered models, prioritizing communal unity, while Shia tafsir integrated the Imamate into its hermeneutics. Practically, Shia interpretations may reinforce adherence to clerical guidance as an extension of prophetic legacy, whereas Sunni readings often emphasize individual accountability within the ummah’s collective framework. Both traditions, however, uphold the verse’s ethical core: rejecting materialism and prioritizing transcendent accountability, as noted across all cited sources. These nuanced differences illustrate how theological heritage shapes textual engagement without undermining shared ethical principles.

73.layer1:
This verse from Surah Yunus recounts the story of Prophet Nuh (Noah) and his people, capturing a timeless lesson about divine justice and human responsibility. When Nuh tirelessly called his people to worship Allah and abandon corruption, they rejected him (kadhdhabuhu), mocking his message despite his centuries of patience. Allah’s response was twofold: salvation for believers and destruction for deniers. Nuh and his followers were saved in the ark (fulk), a vessel symbolizing divine protection and mercy, while the disbelievers drowned—a consequence of their arrogance and rejection of clear signs (ayatina). The phrase "made them successors" (ja’alnahum khala’if) highlights believers’ role as stewards entrusted with nurturing justice and morality on Earth, a responsibility echoing through generations.

Revealed during the Meccan period, when early Muslims faced intense persecution, this verse reassured the oppressed community that truth ultimately prevails. The Arabic term khala’if (successors) carries deep significance, rooted in the concept of inheriting authority with accountability. Just as Nuh’s followers rebuilt society after the flood, Muslims are called to uphold ethical leadership and communal welfare. The command to "see how was the end of those who were warned" urges reflection on history’s patterns: arrogance and denial lead to ruin, while faith and perseverance yield redemption.

Today, this verse inspires Muslims to remain steadfast amid modern challenges—whether facing moral decay, social injustice, or environmental crises. As khala’if, we must champion compassion, protect vulnerable communities, and care for creation. The story also underscores collective resilience; just as the ark carried Nuh’s community to safety, unity and shared faith empower believers to navigate trials. Let this verse remind us that heedlessness has consequences, but sincere trust in Allah transforms trials into opportunities for growth, aligning our actions with the legacy of the righteous.
73.layer2:
In Surah Yunus verse 73, the Qur'an recounts Prophet Nuh's ordeal with his people, their rejection of divine truth, and the consequent divine retribution. Classical Shia commentaries, deeply rooted in the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt, situate this narrative within broader theological frameworks of divine justice (*'adl*), prophetic mission (*nubuwwah*), and the principle of divinely ordained succession (*khilafah*). 

Al-Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, underscores the verse's emphasis on the cyclical pattern of divine guidance and human response: communities rejecting prophets face destruction, while the faithful are preserved as inheritors of spiritual and temporal authority. The phrase "made them successors" (*ja'alnahum khala'if*) is interpreted not merely as physical inheritance of land but as a spiritual mandate. This aligns with the Shia understanding of *khilafah* as a continuum of divinely appointed leadership, wherein true successors—like the Imams—inherit the prophets' roles as custodians of revelation and guides for humanity. Al-Tabrisi notes that Nuh's ark symbolises the salvific role of adherence to divine authority, prefiguring the necessity of clinging to the "ship of salvation" embodied by the Ahl al-Bayt, as narrated in prophetic traditions.

For Al-Tabatai in *Al-Mizan*, the drowning of the disbelievers exemplifies divine justice: their rejection of "Our signs" (*ayatina*) reflects not mere denial of miracles but a deeper rebellion against ontological truth (*haqq*). The "signs" encompass both cosmic proofs of God's unity and the ethical imperatives conveyed through prophets. Shia theology posits that such rejection constitutes a violation of the covenant of recognition (*mithaq al-ma'rifah*), wherein humanity's primordial duty is to acknowledge divine guides. Thus, the verse implicitly affirms the Shia doctrine that rejecting the Imam of one's time equates to rejecting prophethood itself—a principle reiterated in narrations from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq.

The verse's closing admonition—"see how was the end of those who were warned"—serves as a jurisprudential axiom, reinforcing the concept of *indhar* (divine warning) central to Islamic eschatology. Classical commentators link this to the Shia ethical-juridical principle that knowledge of truth imposes moral responsibility (*taklif*), with eternal consequences for its acceptance or rejection. The narrative thus transcends historical account, becoming a timeless paradigm of the cosmic struggle between truth and falsehood, resolved eternally through divine justice and the triumph of the guided.
73.layer3:
In Surah Yunus, verse 73, the story of Prophet Nuh (Noah) serves as a timeless parable of divine justice, collective responsibility, and resilience against oppression. Contemporary Shia scholars, like Ayatollah Mohammad Ali Shomali, emphasize this narrative’s dual focus: the moral duty to heed divine guidance and the societal consequences of rejecting it. The “ship” symbolizes not just physical salvation but the necessity of building ethical, inclusive communities amid crises—a theme echoing modern challenges like climate collapse, systemic injustice, and political authoritarianism.  

Scientifically, the flood narrative invites reflection on humanity’s relationship with nature. Scholars such as Dr. Seyyed Hossein Nasr have linked ecological destruction to spiritual neglect, framing climate change as a “modern flood” wrought by ignoring the “signs” (ayat) embedded in natural balance. The verse’s warning—*“see how was the end of those who were warned”*—resonates starkly in an era of melting ice caps and deforestation, urging stewardship aligned with Quranic principles of *khalifa* (stewardship).  

Socially, the drowning of deniers underscores the perils of entrenched inequity. Ayatollah Taqi al-Modarresi interprets the “successors” (khala’if) as communities tasked with establishing justice after oppression—a call relevant to movements addressing racism, poverty, and displacement. The ark, as a multicultural space preserving life, also models interfaith solidarity; parallels with Biblical and Indigenous flood stories remind us that ethical imperatives transcend religious boundaries.  

Today, the verse challenges us to construct “arks” of hope: resilient institutions, climate action, and cross-cultural dialogue. As contemporary Shia thinker Dr. Liyakat Takim notes, the story’s urgency lies in its demand for proactive faith—a faith that doesn’t merely await salvation but actively labors for it. In a fractured world, Nuh’s legacy is a compass, directing us toward collective survival rooted in justice, wisdom, and reverence for the interconnected “signs” of creation.
73.layer4:
The verse of Noah’s Ark in Surah Yunus echoes the eternal pattern of divine truth: truth is always resisted, yet divinely preserved through the steadfast and their successors. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) taught that salvation lies in clinging to the Ark of Divine Guidance, just as Noah’s followers were saved by boarding the physical ark. Imam Ali (as) said, *“The example of us, the Ahlul Bayt, is like the Ark of Noah—whoever boards it is saved, and whoever abandons it drowns.”* This metaphor reveals the necessity of Wilayah (divine guardianship) as the vessel of salvation. Those who reject the “signs” of Allah, as the verse states, are not merely denying miracles but refusing the living guidance of the Imams, who are the walking Qur’an and the preserved Light of Allah on Earth.

The drowning of the deniers teaches the consequence of turning away from the Imamah. Imam Sadiq (as) explained, *“When people abandon their Imam, the earth swallows them as the sea swallowed Pharaoh’s people.”* The “successors” mentioned in the verse are not only political rulers but inheritors of prophetic wisdom. Just as Allah established Noah’s faithful as heirs to a renewed creation, the Imams are the inheritors of Muhammad’s (pbuh) mission, reviving spiritual life in every age. Lady Fatimah (as) encapsulated this truth in her famous sermon: *“Allah made obedience to us the foundation of His religion and our Wilayah its fortress.”*

Practically, this verse calls believers to anchor themselves to the Ark of the Ahlul Bayt amidst life’s storms. Daily, we must renew our allegiance (bay’ah) through sincere dua, ethical conduct mirroring the Imams’ virtues, and seeking knowledge from their purified teachings. Imam Zayn al-Abidin (as) taught in Sahifa Sajjadiyya: *“O Allah, make me among those who cling to the rope of their love and follow their footsteps!”* Let every denial of truth around us strengthen our resolve to embody the Ark’s passengers—humble in faith, loyal to the saved sect, and awake to the warning that heedlessness drowns the soul.

سور Surah یونس آیت 73 میں ، قرآن نے اپنے لوگوں کے ساتھ نبی نبی کی آزمائش ، الہی سچائی کو مسترد کرنے ، اور اس کے نتیجے میں الہی بدلہ لیا۔ کلاسیکی شیعہ تبصرے ، جو اہل البائٹ کی تعلیمات پر گہری جڑیں ہیں ، اس داستان کو خدائی انصاف (*'ایڈل*) ، پیشن گوئی مشن (*نوبووہ*) کے وسیع تر مذہبی فریم ورک کے اندر پیش کرتے ہیں ، اور خدائی مقرر کردہ جانشینی کے اصول (*خلفاہ*)۔ 

الاتبریسی ، *مجس البیان *میں ، الہی رہنمائی اور انسانی ردعمل کے چکرمک طرز پر آیت کے زور کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے: انبیاء کو مسترد کرنے والی جماعتوں کو تباہی کا سامنا کرنا پڑتا ہے ، جبکہ وفادار روحانی اور عارضی اتھارٹی کے وارث کے طور پر محفوظ ہیں۔ "ان کو جانشین بنادیا" کے فقرے (*ja'alnahum خلعف*) کی ترجمانی محض زمین کی جسمانی وراثت نہیں بلکہ روحانی مینڈیٹ کے طور پر کی جاتی ہے۔ یہ * خلافہ * کے بارے میں شیعہ تفہیم کے ساتھ الہی مقرر کردہ قیادت کے تسلسل کے طور پر ہم آہنگ ہے ، جس میں حقیقی جانشین جیسے اماموں کی طرح ، نبیوں کے کردار کو انسانیت اور رہنمائی کے متولی کے طور پر شامل کرتے ہیں۔ الاتبریسی نے نوٹ کیا ہے کہ نوہ کا صندوق الہی اتھارٹی کی پابندی کے نجات کے کردار کی علامت ہے ، جس سے اے ایچ ایل البیٹ کے ذریعہ "نجات کے جہاز" سے چمٹے رہنے کی ضرورت کو پیش کیا گیا ہے ، جیسا کہ پیشن گوئی کی روایات میں بیان کیا گیا ہے۔

*المزان*میں الاتاباتائی کے لئے ، کافروں کے ڈوبنے سے خدائی انصاف کی مثال ملتی ہے: ان کے "ہماری علامتوں" (*آیتینا*) کو مسترد کرنا معجزات سے محض انکار نہیں بلکہ اونٹولوجیکل سچائی (*حق*) کے خلاف گہری بغاوت کی عکاسی کرتا ہے۔ "نشانیاں" خدا کے اتحاد کے دونوں کائناتی ثبوتوں اور انبیاء کے ذریعہ اخلاقی لازمی ثبوتوں کو گھیرے ہوئے ہیں۔ شیعہ الہیات کا کہنا ہے کہ اس طرح کے مسترد ہونے والے عہد نامے (*میتھاق المعریفاہ*) کی خلاف ورزی کی تشکیل کی گئی ہے ، جس میں انسانیت کا بنیادی فرض الہی رہنماؤں کو تسلیم کرنا ہے۔ اس طرح ، آیت شیعہ کے نظریے کی واضح طور پر تصدیق کرتی ہے کہ کسی کے زمانے کے امام کو مسترد کرنا خود ہی پیشن گوئی کو مسترد کرنے کے مترادف ہے۔

آیت کی بند ہونے والی نصیحت - "دیکھیں کہ ان لوگوں کا خاتمہ کس طرح تھا جن کو متنبہ کیا گیا تھا" - اسلامی اسکیٹولوجی کے مرکزی * اندھار * (خدائی انتباہ) کے تصور کو تقویت بخشنے کے لئے ، فقہی محور کی حیثیت سے پیش کرتا ہے۔ کلاسیکی مبصرین اس کو شیعہ اخلاقی جوریڈیکل اصول سے جوڑتے ہیں کہ حقیقت کا علم اخلاقی ذمہ داری (*تکلیف*) کو اس کی قبولیت یا مسترد ہونے کے دائمی نتائج کے ساتھ مسلط کرتا ہے۔ اس طرح یہ داستان تاریخی اکاؤنٹ سے بالاتر ہے ، جو سچائی اور باطل کے مابین کائناتی جدوجہد کا ایک لازوال نمونہ بنتا ہے ، جو الہی انصاف اور رہنمائی کی فتح کے ذریعہ ہمیشہ کے لئے حل ہوتا ہے۔
73.layer3_urdu:
سورہ یونس میں ، آیت 73 ، نبی نبی (نوح) کی کہانی الہی انصاف ، اجتماعی ذمہ داری ، اور ظلم کے خلاف لچک کی ایک بے وقت تمثیل کی حیثیت سے کام کرتی ہے۔ عصر حاضر کے شیعہ اسکالرز ، جیسے آیت اللہ محمد علی شومالی ، اس داستان کی دوہری توجہ پر زور دیتے ہیں: الہی رہنمائی پر توجہ دینے کا اخلاقی فرض اور اس کو مسترد کرنے کے معاشرتی نتائج۔ "جہاز" نہ صرف جسمانی نجات کی علامت ہے بلکہ بحرانوں کے درمیان اخلاقی ، جامع برادریوں کی تعمیر کی ضرورت کی بھی علامت ہے۔ یہ ایک ایسا موضوع ہے جس میں آب و ہوا کے خاتمے ، نظامی ناانصافی اور سیاسی آمریت پسندی جیسے جدید چیلنجوں کی بازگشت ہے۔  

سائنسی طور پر ، سیلاب کی داستان فطرت کے ساتھ انسانیت کے تعلقات پر عکاسی کی دعوت دیتی ہے۔ ڈاکٹر سیئڈ حسین نصر جیسے اسکالرز نے ماحولیاتی تباہی کو روحانی نظرانداز سے جوڑ دیا ہے ، اور آب و ہوا کی تبدیلی کو قدرتی توازن میں شامل "علامتوں" (آیت) کو نظرانداز کرتے ہوئے "جدید سیلاب" کے طور پر آب و ہوا کی تبدیلی کا آغاز کیا ہے۔ آیت کی انتباہ -*"دیکھیں کہ ان لوگوں کا خاتمہ کیسا تھا جن کو متنبہ کیا گیا تھا"* - پگھلنے والی برف کی ٹوپیوں اور جنگلات کی کٹائی کے دور میں گونجتا ہے ، اور اس پر زور دیا گیا ہے کہ وہ*خلیفہ*(ذمہ داری) کے قرآنی اصولوں کے ساتھ منسلک ہے۔  

معاشرتی طور پر ، انکاروں کو ڈوبنے سے عدم مساوات کے خطرات کی نشاندہی ہوتی ہے۔ آیت اللہ تقی الڈارسی نے "جانشینوں" (خلابف) کی ترجمانی کی ہے جس میں ظلم و ستم کے بعد انصاف کے قیام کا کام سونپا گیا ہے۔ صندوق ، ایک کثیر الثقافتی جگہ کے طور پر زندگی کو محفوظ رکھنے کے طور پر ، بین الاقوامی سطح پر یکجہتی کے ماڈل بھی بناتا ہے۔ بائبل اور دیسی سیلاب کی کہانیاں کے متوازی ہمیں یاد دلاتے ہیں کہ اخلاقی لازمی مذہبی حدود سے بالاتر ہے۔  

آج ، آیت ہمیں امید کے "آرکس" کی تعمیر کے ل challenges چیلنج کرتی ہے: لچکدار ادارے ، آب و ہوا کی کارروائی ، اور ثقافتی بات چیت۔ جیسا کہ عصری شیعہ مفکر ڈاکٹر لییاکات تکیم نے نوٹ کیا ہے ، کہانی کی عجلت اس کے فعال عقیدے کے مطالبے میں ہے۔ یہ ایک ایسا عقیدہ ہے جو محض نجات کا انتظار نہیں کرتا بلکہ اس کے لئے فعال طور پر مشقت کرتا ہے۔ ایک فریکچرڈ دنیا میں ، نوح کی میراث ایک کمپاس ہے ، جس نے ہمیں انصاف ، حکمت اور تخلیق کے باہم مربوط "علامتوں" کے لئے عقیدت سے جڑے ہوئے اجتماعی بقا کی طرف ہدایت کی ہے۔
73.layer4_urdu:
سورہ یونس میں نوح کے صندوق کی آیت الہی سچائی کے دائمی انداز کی بازگشت کرتی ہے: سچائی کا ہمیشہ مزاحمت کیا جاتا ہے ، پھر بھی خدائی طور پر ثابت قدمی اور ان کے جانشینوں کے ذریعے محفوظ رہتا ہے۔ اہل بیت (ان پر امن ہے) نے یہ سکھایا کہ نجات الہی رہنمائی کے صندوق سے چمٹے رہنے میں ہے ، جس طرح نوح کے پیروکار جسمانی کشتی میں سوار ہو کر بچائے گئے تھے۔ امام علی (ع) نے کہا ، * "ہماری مثال ، اہل بیت ، نوح کے صندوق کی طرح ہے - جو اسے بچایا جاتا ہے ، اور جو بھی اسے چھوڑ دیتا ہے اسے ڈوب جاتا ہے۔" وہ لوگ جو اللہ کی "علامتوں" کو مسترد کرتے ہیں ، جیسا کہ آیت میں کہا گیا ہے کہ وہ محض معجزات سے انکار نہیں کررہے ہیں بلکہ وہ اماموں کی زندہ رہنمائی سے انکار کر رہے ہیں ، جو زمین پر چلنے والے قرآن اور اللہ کی محفوظ روشنی ہیں۔

انکار کرنے والوں کو ڈوبنے سے امامہ سے منہ موڑنے کا نتیجہ سکھاتا ہے۔ امام صادق (ع) نے وضاحت کی ، * "جب لوگ اپنے امام کو ترک کرتے ہیں تو ، زمین انہیں نگل جاتی ہے جب سمندر نے فرعون کے لوگوں کو نگل لیا۔" * آیت میں مذکور "جانشین" نہ صرف سیاسی حکمران ہیں بلکہ پیشن گوئی کی دانشمندی کے وارث ہیں۔ جس طرح اللہ نے نوح کے وفادار کو ایک نئی تخلیق کے ورثاء کے طور پر قائم کیا ، اسی طرح امام محمد (ص) مشن کے وارث ہیں ، جو ہر دور میں روحانی زندگی کو زندہ کرتے ہیں۔ لیڈی فاطمہ (ع) نے اپنے مشہور خطبہ میں اس سچائی کو سمیٹ لیا: *"اللہ نے ہمارے مذہب اور ہمارے ولیہ کی اس کے قلعے کی بنیاد ہم کی اطاعت کی۔" *

عملی طور پر ، یہ آیت مومنوں کو زندگی کے طوفانوں کے درمیان اہل بیت کے صندوق پر اپنے آپ کو لنگر انداز کرنے کا مطالبہ کرتی ہے۔ روزانہ ، ہمیں اپنی بیعت (بے یہ) کو مخلص دعا ، اخلاقی طرز عمل کے ذریعے ، اماموں کی خوبیوں کی عکس بندی کرنے اور ان کی پاکیزہ تعلیمات سے علم کے حصول کے لئے تجدید کرنا چاہئے۔ امام زین العبدین (ع) ساہفا سججدیہ میں پڑھائی گئی: * "اے اللہ ، مجھے ان لوگوں میں شامل کریں جو ان کی محبت کی رسی سے چمٹے ہوئے ہیں اور ان کے نقش قدم پر چلتے ہیں!" * ہمارے ارد گرد کے ہر حقیقت سے انکار کی وجہ سے صندوق کے مسافروں کو جذبات سے دوچار کرنے کے لئے ہمارے عزم کو تقویت ملتی ہے۔
73.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Yunus 10:73, both Shia and Sunni exegetical traditions converge on the verse’s core narrative: Prophet Nuh’s rejection by his people, his salvation alongside believers in the ark, and the divine punishment of disbelievers. Scholars across traditions, including Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) in *Majma al-Bayan*, affirm this as a universal lesson on the consequences of rejecting prophets and God’s signs, emphasizing divine justice and mercy. The term *khala’if* (successors) is broadly understood as humanity’s role in inheriting the earth, with Al-Qurtubi (Sunni) and Al-Tusi (Shia) in *Al-Tibyan* noting its alignment with Quranic themes of vicegerency (2:30).  

Divergences emerge in theological nuance. Shia commentaries, particularly Al-Tababatai’s *Al-Mizan*, often contextualize *khala’if* within the framework of *Imamah*, interpreting succession as divinely guided leadership perpetuated through the Ahlul Bayt. Al-Qummi’s *Tafsir* links this to the necessity of unwavering allegiance to righteous leaders, reflecting Shia emphasis on spiritual and temporal authority. Sunni scholars like Ibn Kathir, while acknowledging leadership’s importance, focus on communal righteousness, with Al-Razi’s *Mafatih al-Ghayb* framing succession as a collective responsibility contingent on moral adherence.  

Historically, these differences stem from distinct theological developments: Shia exegesis evolved alongside doctrines of Imamah post the Prophet’s succession debates, while Sunni interpretations often prioritized communal consensus (*ijma*). Such variances subtly influence religious practice, with Shia thought underscoring loyalty to Imams as an extension of prophetic legacy, whereas Sunni perspectives emphasize community-led stewardship. Both traditions, however, uphold the verse’s ethical imperative to heed divine warnings, demonstrating how shared scripture fosters complementary insights within Islamic hermeneutics.
73.layer5_urdu:
سورہ یونس 10:73 کی ترجمانی کرتے ہوئے ، شیعہ اور سنی دونوں روایات آیت کی بنیادی داستان پر ایک دوسرے کے ساتھ مل جاتی ہیں: نبی نے اپنے لوگوں کی طرف سے نبی کریم صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم ، صندوق میں ماننے والوں کے ساتھ ساتھ اس کی نجات اور کفروں کی الہی سزا۔ روایات کے اسکالرز ، بشمول التاباری (سنی) اور الاتبریسی (شیعہ) *ماجما البیان *میں ، نبیوں اور خدا کی علامتوں کو مسترد کرنے کے نتائج پر ایک عالمی سبق کے طور پر اس کی تصدیق کرتے ہیں ، اور الہی انصاف اور رحمت پر زور دیتے ہیں۔ اصطلاح * خلاب * (جانشین) کو بڑے پیمانے پر زمین کو وراثت میں بنانے میں انسانیت کے کردار کے طور پر سمجھا جاتا ہے ، جس میں * التبیان * میں القوروبی (سنی) اور التوسی (شیعہ) کے ساتھ ، وائسجریسی (2:30) کے قرآنی موضوعات کے ساتھ اس کی سیدھ کو نوٹ کیا گیا ہے۔  

مذہبی نوادرات میں تفریق پیدا ہوتی ہے۔ شیعہ کی تفسیر ، خاص طور پر الاتاباتائی کے *المزان *، اکثر *امامہ *کے فریم ورک کے اندر *خلال’یف *کو سیاق و سباق سے دوچار کرتے ہیں ، اور جان کی رہنمائی کی قیادت کے طور پر تعبیر کرتے ہیں جو اہل بائٹ کے ذریعے برقرار رہتے ہیں۔ القمی کا * طافسیر * اس کو راستباز قائدین سے غیر متزلزل بیعت کی ضرورت سے جوڑتا ہے ، جو روحانی اور وقتی اتھارٹی پر شیعہ پر زور دینے کی عکاسی کرتا ہے۔ ابن کتھیر جیسے سنی اسکالرز ، قیادت کی اہمیت کو تسلیم کرتے ہوئے ، فرقہ وارانہ راستبازی پر توجہ مرکوز کرتے ہوئے ، اخلاقی پابندی پر اجتماعی ذمہ داری کے طور پر الراجی کے * مافاتیہ الغیب * جانشینی کے ساتھ کامیابی حاصل کرتے ہیں۔  

تاریخی طور پر ، یہ اختلافات الگ الگ مذہبی پیشرفتوں سے پیدا ہوتے ہیں: شیعہ کی اصلاح امامہ کے نظریات کے ساتھ ساتھ نبی of کے جانشینی کے مباحثوں کے بعد تیار ہوئی ، جبکہ سنی تشریحات اکثر فرقہ وارانہ اتفاق رائے کو ترجیح دیتے ہیں (*IJMA*)۔ اس طرح کی مختلف حالتیں مذہبی رواج پر پوری طرح اثر انداز ہوتی ہیں ، شیعہ نے اماموں کے ساتھ وفاداری کو پیشن گوئی کی وراثت کی توسیع کے طور پر ظاہر کیا ہے ، جبکہ سنی نقطہ نظر برادری کے زیرقیادت نگرانی پر زور دیتا ہے۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات الہی انتباہات پر توجہ دینے کے لئے آیت کی اخلاقی لازمی کو برقرار رکھتی ہیں ، جس سے یہ ظاہر ہوتا ہے کہ مشترکہ صحیفہ اسلامی ہرمینیٹکس کے اندر تکمیلی بصیرت کو کس طرح فروغ دیتا ہے۔
73.summary: Drawing from Al-Mizan, Allama Tabatabai explains that drowning of the disbelievers exemplifies divine justice: their rejection of "Our signs" (*ayatina*) reflects not mere denial of miracles but a deeper rebellion against ontological truth (*haqq*). This verse from Surah Yunus recounts the story of Prophet Nuh (Noah) and his people, capturing a timeless lesson about divine justice and human responsibility. When Nuh tirelessly called his people to worship Allah and abandon corruption, they rejected him (kadhdhabuhu), mocking his message despite his centuries of patience. Allah’s response was twofold: salvation for believers and destruction for deniers. Imam Ali (as) said, *“The example of us, the Ahlul Bayt, is like the Ark of Noah—whoever boards it is saved, and whoever abandons it drowns. Let this verse remind us that heedlessness has consequences, but sincere trust in Allah transforms trials into opportunities for growth, aligning our actions with the legacy of the righteous.

74.layer1:
In Surah Yunus, verse 74, Allah describes a recurring pattern in human history: communities rejecting divine guidance despite overwhelming evidence. The verse begins by noting that after the time of a prophet—commonly understood to refer to Prophet Nuh (Noah)—Allah sent *rusul* (messengers) to their own people with *bayyinat* (clear proofs), such as miracles, logical arguments, and moral teachings. Yet those who had already rejected truth in the past persisted in denial, leading Allah to "seal over the hearts of the *mu'tadeen* (transgressors)." This "sealing" is not arbitrary but a spiritual consequence of their repeated, willful rejection of truth and violation of ethical boundaries. The Arabic term *nata'u* (to seal) implies a covering that grows from persistent wrongdoing, hardening hearts against guidance.  

Historically, this verse reflects the experiences of prophets like Hud, Salih, and others whose communities dismissed their messages despite witnessing miracles. In a Shia context, this aligns with teachings about the necessity of divine guides—like the Imams from the Ahlul Bayt—who continue conveying truth to humanity. The *bayyinat* are not limited to physical miracles but include intellectual, moral, and spiritual clarity offered by Allah’s representatives in every era.  

For modern Muslims, this verse serves as a warning against arrogance and complacency. It urges self-reflection: Are we dismissing truth due to prejudice, habit, or fear of change? The "sealing" of hearts is a gradual process, preventable through humility, seeking knowledge, and aligning actions with justice. Practically, this means prioritizing sincerity in faith, engaging critically with Quranic teachings and the guidance of the Ahlul Bayt, and resisting the temptation to justify harmful behaviors. By recognizing that spiritual blindness stems from repeated transgression, believers can actively nurture openness to truth and accountability in their daily lives.
74.layer2:
In Surah Yunus (10:74), Allah describes the recurrence of prophetic missions and the persistent rejection of divine guidance by transgressors. Classical Shia exegetes, such as Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan*, contextualize this verse within the framework of divine justice (*‘adl*) and human accountability, emphasizing the reciprocity between moral corruption and spiritual blindness. The verse underscores that after Prophet Nuh (as), successive messengers were sent to their respective communities with *bayyinat*—irrefutable proofs encompassing miracles, rational arguments, and moral directives. Despite this, those who habitually rejected truth were rendered incapable of faith due to their entrenched arrogance and transgression (*i‘tida*).  

Tabrisi explains in *Majma al-Bayan* that the phrase "they were not to believe in that which they had denied before" reflects a self-imposed spiritual incapacity, where persistent rejection hardens the heart, making it impervious to guidance. This is not predestinarian coercion but a consequence of free will: Allah’s "sealing" (*tab‘*) of hearts is the ontological result of human choices, not an arbitrary divine decree. Tabatabai elaborates in *Al-Mizan* that such sealing manifests as a withdrawal of divine grace (*lutf*) from those who systematically oppose truth, aligning with the Shia doctrine that Allah’s justice necessitates giving humanity the capacity to accept or reject guidance without compulsion.  

Theologically, the verse resonates with the Shia understanding of *ghuluww* (excess) in sin—transgressors (*mu‘tadeen*) exceed the bounds of ordinary disbelief, adopting a posture of rebellion that severs their connection to innate *fitrah* (primordial nature). This aligns with Imam Jafar al-Sadiq’s (as) teachings on the soul’s corrosion through willful ignorance. Jurisprudentially, the verse reinforces the necessity of divine messengers and, by extension, the Imams from Ahl al-Bayt (as), whose role is to preserve and clarify the *bayyinat* across generations. Their guidance counters the spiritual despotism of those who, as the verse states, "seal their own hearts" through tyranny and moral excess.  

In sum, this verse integrates Shia themes of prophetic continuity, human moral agency, and the ontological consequences of transgression, affirming that divine judgment is both just and inseparable from human accountability.
74.layer3:
In Surah Yunus 10:74, the Quran describes a recurring spiritual pattern: communities rejecting divine guidance despite clear evidence, leading to a hardening of hearts. Contemporary Shia scholars, like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, interpret this as a warning against intellectual arrogance and systemic oppression. The verse underscores that divine truth persists through successive messengers, but rejection isn’t merely about ignorance—it’s a moral failure rooted in pride and injustice. Modern thinkers, such as Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, frame this as a call to examine societal structures that normalize denial, whether in politics, environmental crises, or social inequities. When power hierarchies profit from falsehood, truth becomes inconvenient, and hearts "seal" through complicity.

Neuroscience offers a parallel: repeated denial entrenches cognitive biases, creating neural pathways resistant to change. This "spiritual calcification," as philosopher Dr. Mostafa Malakian notes, mirrors the Quranic concept of hearts sealed by persistent transgression. Socially, the verse resonates with issues like climate denialism or vaccine hesitancy, where evidence is dismissed not for lack of clarity but because it disrupts entrenched ideologies or privileges.

Globally, the verse critiques cultures of exploitation—corporations dismissing ecological collapse, regimes silencing dissent. Yet it also invites interfaith reflection: Buddhist teachings on attachment’s delusions, Christian warnings against hardened hearts (Mark 8:17), and secular ethics on confirmation bias all echo this Quranic insight. Multicultural dialogue, as advocated by scholars like Reza Shah-Kazemi, can revive humility—recognizing truth beyond tribalism.

Ultimately, the verse isn’t about predestined damnation but consequence. As contemporary theologian Dr. Liyakat Takim explains, divine justice operates through cause and effect: hearts close when we choose self-interest over moral courage. The challenge today is to break cycles of denial, whether in combating misinformation or fostering collective accountability—a task demanding both faith and critical engagement.
74.layer4:
In Surah Yunus, verse 74, Allah unveils a profound spiritual law: when communities persistently deny divine proofs, their hearts become sealed by their own transgression. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) illuminate this truth through teachings that bridge the Quran’s warnings with the eternal reality of Imamah and the necessity of clinging to Wilayah (divinely ordained guardianship). Imam Ali (as) explains in *Nahjul Balagha*: "The heart is the sanctuary of Allah; do not seat anyone therein except Allah." A heart that habitually rejects truth becomes a prison of its own making, barricaded by arrogance and rebellion against the Guides sent to nurture it.  

The verse’s reference to messengers bringing "clear proofs" resonates with the Shia understanding of the Imams as living embodiments of divine guidance after the Prophet (pbuh). Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) states: "We are the Proofs of Allah for His creation, and we are the mediators between Allah and His servants." To deny the Imams—the inheritors of prophetic light—after recognizing their truth is to echo the fatal pride of ancient rejecters. Lady Fatimah (as) warned in her historic sermon: "Allah made obedience to us the system for the Ummah and our Imamah a protection against disunity." Rejecting this divinely appointed refuge invites the spiritual blindness described in the verse.  

Practical wisdom from the Ahlul Bayt teaches that safeguarding the heart begins with daily accountability. Imam Zain al-Abidin (as) prays in *Sahifa Sajjadiyya*: "O Allah, bless Muhammad and his family, and replace the hardness of my heart with gentle awareness of Your presence." Regular reflection on one’s intentions, coupled with adherence to the Imams’ teachings, dissolves layers of ego. Reciting the Quran with the lens of the Ahlul Bayt’s interpretations, performing acts of charity in their name, and seeking their intercession through duas like Ziyarat Ashura fortify the soul against transgression.  

Ultimately, this verse underscores that Imamah is Allah’s mercy—a lifeline to prevent hearts from fossilizing. As Imam Ali (as) counsels: "The one who recognizes his Imam will never be barred from guidance." Surrendering to the cosmic reality of Wilayah is the antidote to the disease of arrogance, unlocking the sealed heart to eternal light.

74.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Yunus 10:74, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core theological principles while demonstrating distinct emphases reflective of their intellectual traditions. The verse’s central theme—divine sealing of hearts as a consequence of persistent rejection—is universally acknowledged across traditions. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and al-Tabrisi (Shia) both contextualize the verse within prophetic history, noting that successive messengers faced rejection from communities already entrenched in denial. Ibn Kathir and al-Tabtabai (Shia) similarly stress that divine sealing follows willful human transgression, not arbitrary predestination, preserving divine justice (ʿadl) while affirming human accountability—a point echoed in al-Mizan and Tafsir al-Qurtubi.

Divergences emerge in framing causality. Sunni commentators like al-Razi emphasize Allah’s absolute power (qudra) in shaping hearts, interpreting the “sealing” as a divine response to ingrained disbelief. This aligns with Ashʿari occasionalism, where human acts are “acquired” through God’s will. Shia sources, particularly Tusi’s Al-Tibyan and Qummi’s tafsir, accentuate the role of human agency, framing the verse as a warning against self-inflicted spiritual blindness through repeated sin. This reflects the Muʿtazili-influenced Shia emphasis on rational divine justice, wherein God’s actions respond proportionally to human choices.

Historically, these differences stem from early theological debates on free will versus predestination. The Shia focus on ethical responsibility dovetails with their view of ongoing guidance through Imams, while Sunni readings often prioritize divine transcendence. Practically, both traditions derive a shared ethical imperative: avoiding arrogance and heeding divine signs. However, Shia exegesis may more directly connect this theme to the necessity of recognizing rightful guides (Ahl al-Bayt), as noted in Majma al-Bayan, whereas Sunni works like al-Jami li-Ahkam al-Quran emphasize communal adherence to scripture. These nuances, rooted in distinct theological frameworks, illustrate how shared Quranic principles are enriched through pluralistic scholarly engagement.

75.layer1:
This verse from Surah Yunus recounts Allah’s timeless pattern of sending guidance to humanity through His chosen messengers, even when people persist in arrogance and injustice. After previous generations rejected divine messages, Allah sent Musa (Moses) and Harun (Aaron) to confront Pharaoh and his inner circle with clear *ayatina* (Our signs)—miracles and proofs of truth. Despite witnessing these divine manifestations, Pharaoh’s court *istakbaru* (acted arrogantly), clinging to power and falsehood while oppressing others. Their arrogance led them to reject truth and persist in *mujrimeen* (criminal behavior), exploiting people and denying Allah’s sovereignty.  

Historically, this verse reflects the ongoing struggle between divine guidance and tyrannical power. Pharaoh symbolized worldly arrogance, claiming divinity while enslaving the Bani Israel. Musa and Harun’s mission—backed by miracles like the staff transforming into a serpent—exposed the fragility of Pharaoh’s claims. Yet, as the Quran often emphasizes, miracles alone don’t transform hearts hardened by pride. The verse also subtly critiques collective sin: Pharaoh’s *mala* (inner circle) followed him blindly, showing how corrupt leadership corrupts society.  

The Arabic term *ba’athna* (We sent) underscores Allah’s active role in guiding humanity, choosing messengers to confront oppression. *Istakbaru*—rooted in *kibr* (arrogance)—is a recurring Quranic warning; it signifies rejecting truth to protect one’s ego or status. Today, this verse reminds Muslims to recognize modern forms of *istikbar*: rejecting ethical truths for material gain, oppressing others, or dismissing divine guidance for personal desires. It calls us to support truth-tellers like Musa and Harun in every era—whether scholars, activists, or ordinary people resisting injustice. Practically, this means examining our own hearts for hidden arrogance, challenging unjust systems, and upholding justice even when it challenges entrenched power. As the Ahlul Bayt taught, true faith requires aligning with truth, not convenience.
75.layer2:
In Surah Yunus verse 75, the Qur'an recounts the divine mission of Prophets Musa and Harun to Pharaoh and his ruling elite, who reject their signs with arrogance. Classical Shia commentaries contextualize this narrative within broader theological frameworks, emphasizing themes of divine guidance, human accountability, and the cosmic struggle between truth and falsehood. 

Al-Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, underscores the phrase "with Our signs" as encompassing both tangible miracles (like Musa’s staff and luminous hand) and intellectual proofs, reflecting the comprehensive nature of prophetic evidence. He notes that Pharaoh’s rejection stemmed not from a lack of clarity in the message but from a moral corruption rooted in *istikbar* (arrogance), a state that blinds the soul to truth. This aligns with the Shia emphasis on the necessity of *tawḥīd* (divine unity) as both an intellectual conviction and a surrender of ego—a principle violated by Pharaoh’s claim to divinity. 

Al-Tabtabai’s *Al-Mizan* expands on the theological implications of Pharaoh’s response, framing it as a rejection of *wilāyah* (divine guardianship). Just as Pharaoh denied the authority of Musa—a divinely appointed guide—so too do oppressors across history reject the *walī* (guardian) appointed by God, a theme central to Shia Islam’s understanding of imamate. This verse thus implicitly connects to the broader doctrine of the Imams’ infallible guidance, underscoring humanity’s obligation to recognize and submit to God’s chosen representatives. 

The verse also highlights the interplay between divine justice and human free will. As articulated in Shia theodicy, Pharaoh’s tyranny and his people’s complicity ("they were a criminal people") exemplify moral failure despite clear guidance, affirming that evil arises from conscious choice rather than divine decree. This aligns with jurisprudential principles like *al-amr bi-l-maʿrūf* (enjoining good), which obligates believers to confront injustice actively—a duty mirrored in Musa and Harun’s unwavering stance against oppression. 

Classical commentators universally stress the enduring relevance of this narrative: just as Pharaoh’s court symbolized systemic disbelief, so too do contemporary structures of oppression necessitate resistance through faith and adherence to divine guardianship. The verse thus serves as both a historical account and a timeless call to recognize truth through humility and submission to God’s signs.
75.layer3:
In Surah Yunus, verse 75, the Qur’an recounts Allah sending Musa (Moses) and Harun (Aaron) to Pharaoh and his elite with divine signs, only to be met with arrogance and entrenched corruption. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Mohammad Ali Shomali, emphasize that this narrative transcends history, offering timeless lessons on confronting systemic oppression and moral decay. The verse underscores the clash between divine truth and tyrannical power—a dynamic mirrored in modern struggles against authoritarian regimes, corporate exploitation, and social inequity. The “signs” (ayat) bestowed upon Musa and Harun are interpreted not merely as miracles but as universal proofs of ethical and cosmic order, resonating with scientific calls to recognize natural laws and ecological balance. Scholars like Dr. Muna Tatari highlight how Pharaoh’s arrogance mirrors today’s “arrogance of power,” visible in leaders who prioritize control over justice or dismiss climate science despite overwhelming evidence.  

The verse’s reference to collective criminality (“they were a criminal people”) invites reflection on complicity in unjust systems. Social theorists like Hamid Dabashi link this to modern critiques of institutionalized racism, economic disparity, or militarism, where passive acceptance perpetuates harm. Philosophically, the story challenges us to question what theologian Shabbir Akhtar calls “civilizational hubris”—the assumption that technological or political dominance equates to moral superiority.  

Interfaith parallels emerge here: the Exodus narrative is shared among Judaism, Christianity, and Islam, symbolizing universal resistance to oppression. In multicultural societies, this verse inspires solidarity across faiths in addressing issues like refugee crises or poverty, echoing Pope Francis’s calls for “mercy over might.” Ultimately, this verse urges humility before truth, collective accountability, and the courage to confront Pharaoh-like forces—whether in palaces, boardrooms, or algorithms—guiding us toward justice as both spiritual duty and social imperative.
75.layer4:
The story of Musa and Harun’s confrontation with Pharaoh, as recounted in this verse, holds timeless lessons about divine authority and the spiritual peril of arrogance. The Ahlul Bayt (as) taught that Pharaoh’s rebellion mirrors the universal struggle between truth (haqq) and falsehood (batil), where the rejection of clear signs (ayat) stems not from ignorance, but from the corruption of the heart. Imam Ali (as) states: *“The most burdensome shackle is arrogance, for it chains the intellect to ignorance”* (Ghurar al-Hikam). Here, Pharaoh’s “crime” lies not merely in tyranny but in his refusal to humble himself before the luminous guidance sent through Allah’s chosen messengers – a pattern repeated by those who reject the Wilayah of the Imams (as) in every age.  

Lady Fatimah (as), in her historic sermon, illuminated this truth by declaring: *“Allah made obedience to us the foundation of His religion and Imamate from us a safeguard against division”* (Bihar al-Anwar). Pharaoh’s rejection of Musa’s miracles – which were physical manifestations of divine power – parallels the rejection of the spiritual miracles embodied in the sinless Imams. As Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) taught: *“Our hearts are the vessels of Allah’s will; when He desires something, we desire it”* (Al-Kafi), emphasizing that recognizing divine representatives requires a heart purified from the arrogance that blinded Pharaoh.  

For spiritual development, this verse calls believers to emulate the *sakinah* (divine tranquility) of Musa and Harun rather than Pharaoh’s pride. Practical steps include:  
1. Cultivating daily humility through reflection on one’s dependence on Allah  
2. Seeking knowledge that connects one to the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (as)  
3. Rejecting subtle forms of arrogance in interactions with others  

Imam Zayn al-Abidin (as) guides us in his *Du‘a Makarim al-Akhlaq*: *“Place in my soul faith that overthrows arrogance in my chest!”* True wilayah means internalizing the Quranic warning against Pharaoh’s fate: arrogance hardens hearts until they become incapable of perceiving the Light of Guidance that shines eternally through the Ahlul Bayt (as)
